Def.Name: Ginkgo
Def.Description: Large tree reaching heights of 66' - 115'. Pyramid crown, with a trunk that is usually tapered up to 30".
Def.Leaves: Alternate, fan shaped, 1" - 2" long, 1 1/2" - 3" wide, born singly or clustered on wartlike spur shoots, often notched at the tip. Light green, yellow in autumn.
Def.Twigs: Yellowish green to gray, many wartlike spur shoots, leaf scars have 2 bundle scars; buds are small and reddish brown in color.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Drupe, fleshy, 1" long, yellow, smells very bad when they become overripe, mature in early autumn.
Def.Bark: Gray and slightly rough. Becoming deeply furrowed.
Def.Range: Hardy to zone 4a. Native to China.
Def.Remarks: Widely cultivated and used as food and in medicine. This tree is very similar to fossils that can be found throughout the world, making this tree a living fossil.
